title: Giovanni Gualberto Bottarelli
text:
Giovanni Gualberto Bottarelli wrote the <a href="libretto">libretto</a> for several <a href="opera">opera</a>s to which <a href="Johann%20Christian%20Bach">Johann Christian Bach</a> wrote the music, and adapted many other operas. The first collaboration with Bach was "Orione", performed at the <a href="Her%20Majesty%27s%20Theatre">King's Theatre</a> (now Her Majesty's Theatre) in <a href="Haymarket%2C%20London">Haymarket</a> to great acclaim in February 1763. "<a href="Zanaida">Zanaida</a>", a three-act opera debuted in London in May 1763, but was less well received. Other works were ""Addio di Londra", "Carattaco", "Cesare e Cleopatra", "Il Cid" ", ""L'Endimione", and "Rodelinda regina de' Longobardi"".
"Il ré pastore" (The royal shepherd), adapted by Bottarelli, was printed in London in 1765.
Bottarelli was a witness in a court case against <a href="Giacomo%20Casanova">Casanova</a>, who reported of him "Botarelli publishes in a pamphlet all the ceremonies of the Freemasons, and the only sentence passed on him is: 'He is a scoundrel. We knew that before!'" Casanova also calls Bottarelli a rascal, after meeting him and his family in penury, and reports that Bottarelli had been a monk in his native city, Pisa, and had fled to England with his wife, who had been a nun.
